markdownRemark.excerpt: This is the fourth post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series. In the first three posts, we are acquainted with the fundamental concepts and techniques…
markdownRemark.html:
This is the fourth post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series. In the first three posts, we are acquainted with the fundamental concepts and techniques in group theory. In this post, we will introduce the Sylow theorems.

  • The Sylow’s Theorems
  • References

The Sylow’s Theorems

Proposition 4.1: The Abelian Version of Cauchy’s Theorem

If a group GGG is abelian and p∣∣G∣p \mid |G|p∣∣G∣ where ppp is a prime, GGG has an element of order ppp.

ProofProofProof. The proposition will serve as a preparation for the Sylow’s 1st theorem. We will prove this proposition by induction on the order of GGG . Assume the proposition is true for ∣G∣≤k|G| \leq k∣G∣≤k. For ∣G∣>k|G|>k∣G∣>k, consider x∈G,x≠ex \in G, x \neq ex∈G,x=e, and N=<x>N = <x>N=<x>. There are two cases:

  • If p∣∣x∣,x∣x∣/pp \mid |x|, x^{|x|/p}p∣∣x∣,x∣x∣/p has order ppp.
  • If p∤∣x∣p \nmid |x|p∤∣x∣, note that N⊴GN \trianglelefteq GN⊴G since GGG is abelian, and consider G/NG/NG/N. Since p∤∣x∣,p∣∣G/N∣p \nmid |x|, p \mid |G/N|p∤∣x∣,p∣∣G/N∣. By the inductive hypothesis, we have an element gN∈G/NgN \in G/NgN∈G/N such that ∣gN∣=p|gN| = p∣gN∣=p. Note that (gN)∣g∣=N(gN)^{|g|} = N(gN)∣g∣=N, so p∣∣g∣p \mid |g|p∣∣g∣. Thus, g∣g∣/pg^{|g|/p}g∣g∣/p is an element of order ppp.

Theorem 4.2: The Sylow’s 1st Theorem

If GGG is a group ∣G∣=pam|G| = p^am∣G∣=pam where aaa is a positive integer, ppp is a prime and p∤mp \nmid mp∤m, GGG has a subgroup of order pap^apa. We call a subgroup of order pap^apa a Sylow p-group.

ProofProofProof. We will prove the Sylow’s 1st theorem by induction on the size of GGG. Assume ∣G∣=pam|G| = p^am∣G∣=pam, consider the center Z(G)⊴GZ(G) \trianglelefteq GZ(G)⊴G, the quotient group G/Z(G)G/Z(G)G/Z(G), and the induced homomorphism π:G→G/Z(G)\pi: G \to G/Z(G)π:G→G/Z(G). Note that by tthe fourth isomorphism theorem, if H<G/Z(G)H < G/Z(G)H<G/Z(G), then π−1(H)\pi^{-1}(H)π−1(H) is a subgroup of GGG of order ∣H∣∣Z(G)∣|H||Z(G)|∣H∣∣Z(G)∣. There are two cases of the order of G/Z(G)G/Z(G)G/Z(G):

  • Case1: p∣∣Z(G)∣p \mid |Z(G)|p∣∣Z(G)∣. By Proposition 4.1, Z(G)Z(G)Z(G) has a cyclic group KKK of order ppp. Note that K⊴GK \trianglelefteq GK⊴G and ∣G/K=pa−1m|G/K = p^{a-1}m∣G/K=pa−1m. By the inductive hypothesis, G/KG/KG/K has a Sylow p-group A of order pa−1p^{a-1}pa−1. Consider the induced homomorphism π~:G→G/K\tilde \pi: G \to G/Kπ~:G→G/K. Then π~−1(A)\tilde \pi ^{-1}(A)π~−1(A) has order pap^{a}pa.
  • Case2: p∤∣Z(G)∣p \nmid |Z(G)|p∤∣Z(G)∣. Recall the class equation, ∣G∣=∣Z(G)∣+∑g∈G[G:CG(g)]|G| = |Z(G)|+\sum_{g \in G}[G:C_G(g)]∣G∣=∣Z(G)∣+∑g∈G​[G:CG​(g)]. Since p∤∣Z(G)∣p \nmid |Z(G)|p∤∣Z(G)∣, p∤[G:CG(gi)]=G/CG(gi)p \nmid [G:C_G(g_i)] = G/C_G(g_i)p∤[G:CG​(gi​)]=G/CG​(gi​) for some gi∈Gg_i \in Ggi​∈G, so pa∣CG(gi)p^a \mid C_G(g_i)pa∣CG​(gi​). Since CG(gi)<GC_G(g_i) < GCG​(gi​)<G, by the inductive hypothesis, CG(gi)C_G(g_i)CG​(gi​) has a Sylow p-group of order pap^apa.

Theorem/Corollary 4.3: The Cauchy’s Theorem

If GGG is a group and order of GGG is divisible by a prime ppp, then GGG has an element of order ppp.

ProofProofProof. We can prove the Cauchy’s theorem by using the Sylow’s 1st theorem. If GGG is a group and order of GGG is divisible by a prime ppp, then GGG has a subgroup HHH of order pmp^mpm for some integer mmm. By the Lagarange’s theorem, ∀x∈H,∣x∣=pk\forall x \in H, |x| = p^k∀x∈H,∣x∣=pk where kkk is an integer and 0≤k≤m0 \leq k \leq m0≤k≤m. Consider the element xpk−1x^{p^{k-1}}xpk−1 in the subgroup generated by xxx, ⟨x⟩\langle x \rangle⟨x⟩, ∣xpk−1∣=gcd(pk,pk−1)=p|x^{p^{k-1}}| = gcd(p^k, p^{k-1}) = p∣xpk−1∣=gcd(pk,pk−1)=p.

Definiton 4.4: p-groups

If GGG is a group ∣G∣=pam|G| = p^am∣G∣=pam where aaa is a postive integer, ppp is a prime and p∤mp \nmid mp∤m, we call a subgroup of order that is a power of ppp a p-group, a subgroup of order pap^apa a Sylow p-group. We denote the set of Sylow p-groups Sylp(G)Syl_p(G)Sylp​(G), the number of Sylow p-groups in GGG as np=∣Sylp(G)∣n_p = |Syl_p(G)|np​=∣Sylp​(G)∣.

Theorem 4.5: The Sylow’s 2nd Theorem

If GGG is a group, H<GH < GH<G is a p-group, P<GP<GP<G is a Sylow p-group, there exists a g∈Gg \in Gg∈G such that gHg−1≤PgHg^{-1} \leq PgHg−1≤P.

Corollary 4.6

  1. Any two Sylow p-groups are conjugate and isomorphic to each other.
  2. If P≤GP \leq GP≤G is a Sylow p-group, P⊴GP \trianglelefteq GP⊴G iff np=1n_p = 1np​=1.
  3. If P≤GP \leq GP≤G is a Sylow p-group, np=[G:NG(P)]n_p = [G: N_G(P)]np​=[G:NG​(P)].

ProofProofProof. For the first claim, apply the Sylow’s 2nd theorem directly for HHH being a Sylow p-group. For the second claim, both directions can be shown with the first claim and the definition of normality. For the third claim, note that the action of GGG on Sylp(GSyl_p(GSylp​(G by conjugation is transitive due to the first claim. Therefore, np=∣Sylp(G)n_p = |Syl_p(G)np​=∣Sylp​(G) is the index of the stablizer of a Sylow p-group in GGG, which is NG(P)N_G(P)NG​(P).

Theorem 4.7: The Sylow’s 3rd Theorem

If GGG is a group ∣G∣=pam|G| = p^am∣G∣=pam where aaa is a positive integer, ppp is a prime and p∤mp \nmid mp∤m, then np≡1mod  pn_p \equiv 1 \mod pnp​≡1modp and np∣mn_p \mid mnp​∣m.

To prove the Sylow’s 2nd and 3rd theorems, we first prove a lemma.

Lemma 4.8

If GGG is a group, H<GH < GH<G a subgroup, P<GP < GP<G a Sylow p-group, then NG(P)∩H=P∩HN_G(P) \cap H = P \cap HNG​(P)∩H=P∩H.

ProofProofProof. Put C:=NG(P)∩HC := N_G(P) \cap HC:=NG​(P)∩H. Clearly, P∩H≤CP \cap H \leq CP∩H≤C. We want to show that: C≤P∩H  ⟺  C≤P  ⟺  CP≤PC \leq P \cap H \iff C \leq P \iff CP \leq PC≤P∩H⟺C≤P⟺CP≤P. Since C≤NG(P)C \leq N_G(P)C≤NG​(P), by the second isomorphic theorem, CPCPCP is a subgroup and ∣CP∣=∣C∣∣P∣/∣C∩P∣.Notethatsince|CP| = |C||P|/|C\cap P|. Note that since∣CP∣=∣C∣∣P∣/∣C∩P∣.NotethatsinceHandandandParep−groups,are p-groups,arep−groups,p \mid |C|, p \mid |P|, p \mid |C\cap P|,so, so,sop \mid |CP|.Note. Note.NoteP \leq CPandandandPisaSylowp−group,sois a Sylow p-group, soisaSylowp−group,soCP=P$. This finishes the proof.

Now we can prove the Sylow’s 2nd and 3rd theorems.

ProofProofProof. Suppose Sylp(G)={P1,P2,⋯ ,Pnp}Syl_p(G) = \{P_1, P_2, \cdots, P_{n_p}\}Sylp​(G)={P1​,P2​,⋯,Pnp​​}. Let the set SSS be the subset of Sylp(G)Syl_p(G)Sylp​(G) such that P∈SP \in SP∈S is conjugate to P1P_1P1​. We will prove the Sylow’s 2nd and 3rd theorems in four steps: (a) ∣S∣≡1mod  p|S| \equiv 1 \mod p∣S∣≡1modp; (b) for all p-group HHH, H∈PiH \in P_iH∈Pi​ for some Pi∈SP_i \in SPi​∈S; (c) ∣S∣=np|S| = n_p∣S∣=np​; (d) np∣mn_p \mid mnp​∣m.

(a) Consider the conjugation action of P1P_1P1​ on SSS. Suppose the orbits of the action are O1,O2,⋯ ,OaO_1, O_2, \cdots, O_aO1​,O2​,⋯,Oa​, where O1={P1}O_1 = \{P_1\}O1​={P1​}. The class equation gives

∣S∣=∑i=1a∣Oi∣=1+∑i=2a∣Oi∣=1+∑i=2a∣P1/stab(Pi)∣=1+∑i=2a∣P1/NG(Pi)∩P1∣=1+∑i=2a∣P1/Pi∩P1∣|S| = \sum_{i=1}^a |O_i| = 1 + \sum_{i=2}^a |O_i| = 1 + \sum_{i=2}^a |P_1/stab(P_i)| = 1 + \sum_{i=2}^a |P_1/N_G(P_i) \cap P_1| = 1 + \sum_{i=2}^a |P_1/P_i \cap P_1|∣S∣=∑i=1a​∣Oi​∣=1+∑i=2a​∣Oi​∣=1+∑i=2a​∣P1​/stab(Pi​)∣=1+∑i=2a​∣P1​/NG​(Pi​)∩P1​∣=1+∑i=2a​∣P1​/Pi​∩P1​∣

Thus, ∣S∣≡1mod  p|S| \equiv 1 \mod p∣S∣≡1modp, since p∣∣P1/Pi∩P1∣p \mid |P_1/P_i \cap P_1|p∣∣P1​/Pi​∩P1​∣.

(b) Assume for contradiction that HHH is not contained in any Pi∈SP_i \in SPi​∈S. Consider the action of HHH on SSS by conjugation, orb(Pi)=∣H∣/stab(Pi)orb(P_i) = |H|/stab(P_i)orb(Pi​)=∣H∣/stab(Pi​). Note that stab(Pi)=NG(Pi)∩H=Pi∩Hstab(P_i) = N_G(P_i) \cap H = P_i \cap Hstab(Pi​)=NG​(Pi​)∩H=Pi​∩H, and since H⊄Pi,stab(Pi)⊂HH \not\subset P_i, stab(P_i) \subset HH⊂Pi​,stab(Pi​)⊂H. Thus, ∣orb(Pi)∣≠1|orb(P_i)| \neq 1∣orb(Pi​)∣=1, but orb(Pi)⊆Horb(P_i) \subseteq Horb(Pi​)⊆H, so orb(Pi)∣porb(P_i) \mid porb(Pi​)∣p. Thus, ∣S∣∣p|S| \mid p∣S∣∣p, a contradiction to (a).

(c) This follows directly from (b), since a Sylow p-group is also a p-group. Sylp(G)=SSyl_p(G) = SSylp​(G)=S.

(d) Finally, consider the conjugation action of GGG on Sylp(G)Syl_p(G)Sylp​(G). Note that the action is transitive. We have the class equation np=∣orb(P1)∣=∣G∣/∣stab(P1)∣=∣G∣/∣NG(P1)∣n_p = |orb(P_1)| = |G|/|stab(P_1)| = |G|/|N_G(P_1)|np​=∣orb(P1​)∣=∣G∣/∣stab(P1​)∣=∣G∣/∣NG​(P1​)∣. Since P1⊂NG(P1)P_1 \subset N_G(P_1)P1​⊂NG​(P1​), pa∣∣NG(P1)∣  ⟹  np∣mp^a \mid |N_G(P_1)| \implies n_p \mid mpa∣∣NG​(P1​)∣⟹np​∣m.

References

[1] Siegel, Kyler. MATH GU4041 Introduction to Modern Algebra I. Department of Mathematics, Columbia University. 2019.

[2] Dummit, David and Foote, Richard. Abstract Algebra. Third Edition. John Wiley and Sons, Inc. 2004.

frontmatter.title: Abstract Algebra 04 - The Sylow Theorems
frontmatter.description: This is the fourth post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series. In the first three posts, we are acquainted with the fundamental concepts and techniques in group theory. In this post, we will introduce the Sylow theorems.
